H0.text: Fullerenes are a form of pure carbon that can exist in different arrangements of atoms, along with diamond and graphite.

H1.text: Calcites are the other form of pure carbon, alongside diamond and graphite, that can exist depending on how its atoms are arranged.

H2.text: Lead is the form of pure carbon that can exist in addition to diamond and graphite, depending on how its atoms are arranged.

H3.text: Ligands are the third form of pure carbon that can exist depending on how its atoms are arranged, along with diamond and graphite.

A4.text: Fullerenes are an allotrope of carbon whose molecules consist of carbon atoms connected by single and double bonds so as to form a closed or partially closed mesh.

A5.text: The discovery of fullerenes greatly expanded the number of known allotropes of carbon, which had previously been limited to graphite, diamond, and amorphous carbon such as soot and charcoal.
